Speaking in tongues is also known as glossolalia. There are at least a couple ways of looking at it:
 
 1) The Holy Spirit enters a person and compels them to speak in a unique "holy" language, much in the same fashion that the Apostles did two millenia ago. 
 
 2) A person in a highly emotional state who knows that he or she is expected to perform this behavior, as in many pentacostal "healing" ceremonies, starts unconsciously stringing together nonsense syllables to meet the expectations of the group. 
 
 Consider: 
 a) The Apostles were supposedly able to be understood by people of different nations and languages when they were speaking in tongues. Yet when heard in modern ceremonies that might contain people of many nations, no one is able to understand anything of what's being "said."
 
 b) We think nothing of schizophrenics who engage in the same behavior, excpet to say that Yup, they're crazy alright.
 
 c) Psychologists will tell you that whether you realize it or not, group dynamics and peer pressure are extremely powerful, many times making you do things that wouldn't do otherwise without even realizing it, especially in situations involving supposedly "altered consciousness" where normal behavioral filters go out the window. 
 
 d) Unconscious actions appearing at a conscious level are well documented. The "ideometer effect," for instance, is when unconscious movements guide things like Ouija board indicators, dowsing rods and pendulums. If all these supposedly mystical occurences are shown to have roots in ordinary psychological phenomenon, why would we assume that speaking in tongues is any different, just because it happens in a church instead of a psychic parlor?
